description.narrative: IRC respond to the world’s worst humanitarian crises, helping to restore health, safety, education, economic well being and power to people devastated by conflict and disaster. Their mission is “to help people whose lives and livelihoods have been shattered by conflict and disaster, including the climate crisis, to survive, recover and gain control of their future”. IRC consider their interventions successful when their clients see improvement in their safety from physical, sexual and psychological harm; in their health status, including physical and mental well-being; in education, including literacy and numeracy, social-emotional, and life skills (including safe schools); in economic well-being, including ability to provide basic material needs and income asset growth; and in power to have influence over the decisions that affect their lives. IRC strive to reach these goals while continuously trying to tackle gender inequalities in and through all of their work. As Sida supports IRC in a variety of countries, not one specific objective can be identified for the whole contribution, but for the sake of exemplifying, a number of country specific goals are outlined below: Afghanistan: People meet basic needs and avoid negative coping strategies (economic wellbeing); 6-14-year olds have literacy, numeracy and social-emotional skills, according to their development potential (education). CAR: Children are protected from and treated for communicable diseases (health); People are safe in their communities and receive support when they experience harm (safety); People meet basic needs and avoid negative coping strategies, People generate income and assets (economic wellbeing). South Sudan: People are safe in their communities and receive support when they experience harm (safety); Children are protected from and treated for malnutrition (health); People meet basic needs and avoid negative coping strategies (economic wellbeing). Globally IRC’s largest outcome area is health, with 34 % of all funding being allocated this field in 2019. Across the 15 PBA country programmes relevant for Sida funding in 2021, IRC will pursue health outcomes in eleven programmes, safety in ten, economic well-being in eight, and education and power in one each.

International Rescue Committee, IRC, har inkommit till Sida med en ansökan om finansiering för sina humanitära program i 15 utvalda kriser (Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, Centralafrikanska Republiken, Colombia, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Etiopien, Jemen, Kamerun, Libyen, Mali, Myanmar, Nigeria, Sydsudan, Tchad och Venezuela). Ansökan inkluderar en förfrågan om medel till IRCs snabbfinansieringsmekanism ”Rapid Response Mechanism” vars funktion är att snabbt kunna kanalisera medel till hastigt uppkomna eller kraftigt förvärrade kriser, samt en förfrågan om medel till tre separata projekt för metodstöd och kapacitetsstärkande stöd/externa projekt.
Landprogrammen utgör merparten av förfrågan (176 MSEK), följt av RRM-mekanismen (30 MSEK). Resterande summa (12,55 MSEK) gäller de tre separata projekten, varav ett löper över två år. Ansökan utgörs således av en förfrågan om stöd om 215,9 MSEK för 2021, och 2,65 MSEK för 2022.
IRC är en enskild internationell organisation, aktiv i humanitär respons och utvecklingsarbete i mer än 40 länder globalt. Deras huvudsakliga syfte är att bistå människor vars liv och försörjningsmöjligheter slagits i spillror till följd av konflikter, naturkatastrofer och klimatförändringar genom att erbjuda överlevnadsstöd och aktiviteter för återhämtning. Fokus ligger på aktiviteter inom hälsa, skydd, utbildning, försörjningsmöjligheter samt människors stärkta egenmakt och beslutsförmåga. Huvudsaklig målgrupp är människor som flyr från krig och katastrofer, samt de värdsamhällen som bistår dem.
I dagsläget är IRC huvudsakligen självimplementerande och utför sitt arbete med hjälp av sina 17 000 medarbetare världen över. IRC har däremot ett mål om att utöka sitt samarbete med lokala partners (myndigheter, organisationer, organiserade samhällsgrupper) för att på sikt kanalisera 25 % av finansiella medel genom tredje part, och kommer under 2021 att arbeta för att detta ska bli verklighet.

International Rescue Committee, IRC, has submitted a proposal for financing to Sida for their humanitarian programmes in 15 humanitarian crisis (Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Colombia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Libya, Mali, Myanmar, Nigeria, South Sudan, Venezuela and Yemen) in 2021. The proposal includes a request to fund IRC’s Rapid Response Mechanism, a function which has the purpose of quickly scaling up activities in new or severely deteriorated crisis, as well as a request of funding for three separate projects for method and capacity strengthening / externally run activities.
The country programmes make for the largest part of the request covering 176 MSEK. 30 MSEK are set aside for the RRM mechanism, and the remaining 12.55 MSEK concern the three individual projects, whereof which one is multi-year. Hence, the proposal consists of a funding request for 215.9 MSEK for 2021, and 2.65 MSEK for 2022.
IRC is a non-profit international organisation, working with humanitarian and development work in more than 40 countries world-wide. As per IRC’s mission statement, their goal is “to help people whose lives and livelihoods are shattered by conflict and disaster, including by the climate crisis, to survive, recover and gain control of their future” in the world’s worst humanitarian crisis. Their focus is on activities with the sectors of health, safety/protection, education, livelihoods and ensuring people have the power to influence decisions that affect their lives. Their main target group is people who flee from war, conflict and disaster, and the host communities that support them.
Currently, IRC is mainly a self-implementing organisation who conduct the bulk of their work through their 17 000 global staff members. However, IRC is striving to increase their cooperation with local partners (authorities, organisation, community groups) to reach a goal of sub-granting 25 % of their means through third party, and will work towards achieving this target during 2021.
